skills.name: Add integers with more than 4 digits using a written method where carrying is needed
Subtract integers up to 4 digits using a written method where carrying is needed
Subtract integers with more than 4 digits using a written method where carrying is not needed
Carry out missing number subtraction problems where a written method is needed

explanations.A: What can we subtract 4 from to get an answer of 9? We can do 9+4=13, indicating that there must be some regrouping (borrowing) from the thousands column, but we need to check if any other borrowing has happened earlier. Starting with the units column: 0 − 6 isn't possible, so the top tens change from 2 to 1 and we have 10 − 6 = 4 in the units. The tens column is now 1 − 5, which we can't do, we borrow 1 from the top hundreds, which is ★, the tens answer becomes 11 − 5 = 6. On to the hundreds column, remembering we need to end up calculating 13 − 4 = 9, but that we borrowed 1 for our tens, means that ★ = 3+1 = 4. (The 1 has to be borrowed from the 8 in the thousands column)
explanations.B: I think you've forgotten to check the rest of the calculation - make sure nothing has been borrowed or carried earlier in the calculations.
explanations.C: I think you've calculated 9-4, which will not find ★, as ★ - 4 = 9 cannot be rearranged in this way.
explanations.D: This question is possible. Try to write out the calculation yourself to find what the value must be.

explanations.A: I think you've forgotten to check the rest of the calculation - make sure nothing has been borrowed or carried earlier in the calculations.
explanations.B: We need to consider what we can subtract 3 from to get an answer of 8, so we can do 8+3=11, indicating that there must be some regrouping (borrowing) from the thousands column, we need to check if any happens earlier on. Starting with the units column: 3 − 6 isn't possible, so the top tens change from 1 to 0 and we have 13 − 6 = 7 in the units. The tens column is now 0 − 5, which we can't do, we borrow 1 from the top hundreds, which is ★, the tens answer becomes 10 − 5 = 5. On to the hundreds column, remembering we need to end up calculating 11 − 3 = 8, but that we borrowed 1 for our tens, means that ★ = 1+1 = 2. (The 1 has to be borrowed from the 7 in the thousands column)
explanations.C: I think you've calculated 8-3, which will not find ★, as ★ - 3 = 8 cannot be rearranged in this way.
explanations.D: This question is possible. Try to write out the calculation yourself to find what the value must be.

explanations.A: I think you've forgotten to change your 10's column when you borrowed for the units
explanations.B: You appear to have aligned your numbers incorrectly. Remember you should have units above units first, then tens above tens, hundreds above hundreds, etc.
explanations.C: You appear to have only subtracted 300, forgetting to subtract another 28. Remember you can borrow from higher place value numbers to subtract larger numbers from smaller ones.
explanations.D: Put 328 below 4514, taking care to line up the units, tens, hundreds, etc. Starting with units, 4 − 8, cannot be done, so regrouping (or borrowing) 10 (or 1) from the tens column of 4514 (changing 1 to 0) gives 14 – 8 = 6. Now on to the tens column: this is now 0 subtract 2, so we have to borrow 1 from the 5 in the hundreds column. This becomes 10 - 2 = 8. The next calculation is 4 – 3 = 1 (we reduced 5 when we borrowed). The thousands column is 4 – 0 = 4. This makes our final answer 4186.

explanations.A: Put 578 below 2634, taking care to line up the units, tens, hundreds, etc. Starting with units, 4 − 8, cannot be done, so regrouping (or borrowing) 10 (or 1) from the tens column of 2634 (changing 3 to 2) gives 14 – 8 = 6. Now on to the tens column: this is now 2 subtract 7, so we have to borrow 1 from the 6 in the hundreds column. This becomes 12 - 7 = 5. The next calculation is 5 – 5 = 0 (we reduced 6 when we borrowed). The thousands column is 2 – 0 = 2. This makes our final answer 2056.
explanations.B: You appear to have aligned your numbers incorrectly. Remember you should have units above units first, then tens above tens, hundreds above hundreds, etc.
explanations.C: Remember you have to subtract the number on the bottom row from the one on the top row. You might need to borrow from the next column along to do this.
explanations.D: I think you've forgotten to change the 3 to a 2 when you borrowed to calculate 4-8 in the units column.

explanations.A: You appear to have subtracted here. We are calculating how many people, in total, attended games. This means we are adding the two values together.
explanations.B: You appear to have forgotten to add the carried values in your hundreds column.
explanations.C: You seem to have forgotten to add in the carried numbers. Remember that if 7+8=15, we need to add the 1 in the next column.
explanations.D: Here we need to add the two numbers. Starting with the units, 7+8=15, so 5 goes in the units answer, and we carry 1 to the tens column. 5+7+1=13, so 3 goes in the tens answer, and we carry 1 to the hundreds column. 3+6+1=10, so 0 goes in the hundreds answer, and we carry 1 to the thousands column. 4+3+1=8, so 8 goes in the thousands answer. 5+6=11, so 1 goes in the ten thousands answer, and a 1 goes in the hundred thousands column.

explanations.A: You appear to have subtracted here. We are calculating how many people, in total, attended games. This means we are adding the two values together.
explanations.B: You seem to have forgotten to carry from the 2+7+1 calculation in the tens column.
explanations.C: You seem to have forgotten to carry when the total is more than 9.
explanations.D: Here we need to add the two numbers. Starting with the units, 8+8=16, so 6 goes in the units answer, and we carry 1 to the tens column. 2+7+1=10, so 0 goes in the tens answer, and we carry 1 to the hundreds column. 7+3+1=11, so 1 goes in the hundreds answer, and we carry 1 to the thousands column. 4+6+1=11, so 1 goes in the thousands answer, and we carry 1 to the ten thousands column. Finally 1 goes in the ten thousands column, giving a final answer of 21106.

explanations.A: You've added the values, because Colm gives some money away, this question needs a subtraction.
explanations.B: Colm has given money away, which means we need to subtract the value he gave away.We need to calculate 55,750 – 25,250. The calculation doesn't require any borrowing, and gives an answer of 30,500.
explanations.C: It looks like you've forgotten to subtract the 5 in the thousands column.
explanations.D: You appear to have tried to add the values, making a mistake whilst carrying. Because Colm gives some money away, our calculation will involve a subtraction.

explanations.A: It looks like you've added the two values. If Andy has to spend money, then we need to subtract that from the amount he earns.
explanations.B: It looks like you've done a combination of adding and subtracting here. Make sure you are subtracting the bottom number from the top number every time.
explanations.C: It looks like you've forgotten to subtract the values in the hundreds column. Don't forget to do that part of the calculation! :)
explanations.D: Andy has to spend some of the money, which means we need to subtract that from how much he earns. So we need to calculate 26,358 – 15,320. We don't need to borrow from any of the numbers on the top row, so we get an answer of 11,038.

explanations.A: It looks like you have you've tried to subtract. Remember you need to do the number on the top row take away the number on the bottom. You will need to borrow to do some of these subtractions.
explanations.B: You seem to have added the values together, rather than finding the difference between them.
explanations.C: I think you've made an error copying out the number - notice that the larger number ends 642, and the other number ends 462, which is different, so the last three digits of your answer will not be 000.
explanations.D: It sometimes helps to consider a similar calculation with smaller numbers, eg., 10 – ★ = 8; we know that ★ = 2 and this is because 10 – 2 = 8. Therefore, working out 65,642 – 36,462 will give us the missing answer. Putting the 36,462 below the 65,642, taking care to line up the units, tens, hundreds, etc. and regroup or borrow as needed, gives an answer of 29,180.

explanations.A: It looks like you have you've tried to subtract. Remember you need to do the number on the top row take away the number on the bottom. You will need to borrow to do some of these subtractions.
explanations.B: It sometimes helps to consider a similar calculation with smaller numbers, eg., 10 – ★ = 8; we know that ★ = 2 and this is because 10 – 2 = 8. Therefore, working out 45,872 – 27,415 will give us the missing answer. Putting the 27,415 below the 45,872, taking care to line up the units, tens, hundreds, etc. and regroup or borrow as needed, gives an answer of 18,457.
explanations.C: I think you've forgotten to reduce the numbers you have borrowed from
explanations.D: You seem to have added the values together, rather than finding the difference between them.
